dialogues.text: They're dismantling the entire cockpit around the body.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Well how long's it gonna take? I need an honest, no shit assessment. There's a pause as McKnight relays the question. Then --

dialogues.speaker: MCKNIGHT
dialogues.text: They can't say.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Danny, no one gets left behind. INTERCUT to McKnight --

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You understand me, son? INTERCUT to McKnight. No response.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: Danny? INTERCUT to Garrison. Finally -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MCKNIGHT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, General.

dialogues.speaker: GARRISON
dialogues.text: You do what you have to do.

dialogues.speaker: MCKNIGHT
dialogues.text: Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briley's body is carried away from the Black Hawk

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: 5:45 A.M. - Monday, October 4 Gunfire rains down on the men.

dialogues.speaker: MCKNIGHT
dialogues.text: Let's go! Let's move out! The convoy starts to roll out. Rangers follow on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoot sets explosives in the now-deserted cockpit. Runs to the leaving convoy as the charges are detonated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convoy is picking up speed, the Mountain soldiers scrambling to get aboard Humvees and APCs as Eversmann, Sanderson, and the other Rangers and Delta cover them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the last of the APCs pass, Eversmann and the other Rangers and Delta try to get aboard. EVERY VEHICLE is cra full, some men hanging out open doors, some lying on hood No one stops for them. Steele runs alongside the APC, pou on the metal --

dialogues.speaker: STEELE
dialogues.text: Open up the hatch! We got men back here!

dialogues.speaker: PAKISTANI DRIVER
dialogues.text: No room here, go on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: What's going on? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEELE
dialogues.text: The roof?

dialogues.speaker: TWOMBLY
dialogues.text: I'm not getting on the fucking roof!

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: No, no, no, it's full! The Pakistani driver shouts. Steele shuts the door. There are no more vehicles to chas after.

dialogues.speaker: SANDERSON
dialogues.text: Let's just go, let's just go! The convoy pulls out and the men follow on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city is bathed in orange light. Eversmann, Hoot, Stee Sanderson, Twombly, Sizemore, Nelson, Yurek, Kurth, Wadde Galentine and Doc Schmid are running down the streets aft the convoy, unable to catch up with the vehicles. They watch helplessly as the convoy disappears down the b Their tired, rubbery legs carry them away from the crash site, into the dense, dangerous streets of surrounding neighborhoods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group of soldiers are now running along the same stre they battled over the day before. The men are exhausted, gasping for air as they charge dow the crooked, dirty roads. Legs like lead weights. KRATAKRATAKRAT! Machine-gun fire rakes the road ahead. Th group runs for cover, trying not to get pinned in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rescue Convoy rumbles, stretching back a quarter mile The sound of the vehicles shakes the very earth. An older Somali man carries a dead child and crosses in front of t convoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group runs down the street. Gasping. They can see the convoy disappearing around a corner. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sanderson and Hoot FIRE down the intersection, killing th Somali snipers. Steele, Eversmann and others charge acros On the other side, the Rangers cover Delta Hoot and Sande The Delta Operators charge across to safety. They use this tactic at every intersection. Somali gunfir getting more intense. The men see the APCs, distant block ahead, rounding a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanderson charges up from behind, bullets following him. THEY RUN out into the street as -- A WOMAN with a child i her arms dashes out in front of them, hurrying across the street. Waddell almost fires on instinct.

dialogues.speaker: WADDELL
dialogues.text: Get down, get outta here! The woman runs to the other side of the street. Sanderson runs over to Eversmann.

dialogues.speaker: EVERSMANN
dialogues.text: I'm out of ammo! Sanderson, I'm out of ammo! Sanderson continues to fire. Another woman runs forward, Kurth raises his weapon to fi

dialogues.speaker: YUREK
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: KURTH
dialogues.text: I'm doing it. The woman RAISES A HANDGUN -- Kurth fires and she falls d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group runs down the street, bullets whizzing past. The men charge down the block on wobbly legs, running thr the smoke. People line the streets, cheering them on. They run into the safety of THE SOCCER STADIUM.  281 282 283 124.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entrance is in sight. Doctors are inside, white table and sheets and water and safety and food and shelter and Eversmann makes it. Hoot, Sanderson, Steele, and the othe charge in after him. They stare at the makeshift medical tents that have been up. Watching a Medic directing the seriously wounded to o area, dead to another - as UN workers bring them glasses of water. Nelson and Twombly embrace. Eversmann staggers forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEHIND THEM - Colonel McKnight gets his neck wound looked at.

dialogues.speaker: MCKNIGHT
dialogues.text: Ah, shit.

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: The bullet missed your jugular by about three millimeters. Don't move!

dialogues.speaker: MCKNIGHT
dialogues.text: All right, all right. Hurry up, hurry up! BEHIND HIM - Grimes, covered in white dust, rests on a li Sanderson walks over to him and hands him a cup.

dialogues.speaker: GRIMES
dialogues.text: Little short on coffee, but I got you some tea. How you doing soldier?

dialogues.speaker: RANGER
dialogues.text: I can't feel a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garrison, standing by the door, has come into the chaos t is the medical tent, watching. Somebody shouts,"... mop.. And we see doctors and medics working over a man, the man bleeding profusely, the doctors and the medics literally slipping in his blood on the floor... And Garrison seeing mop nearby takes it up, and doing his duty, mops the bloo floor... And as Garrison mops the bloody floor the doctor and the medics are trying to save his men's lives...  284 285 125.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steele moves through the tent... men in various condition none of it good... He comes to Ruiz. The medic shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: STEELE
dialogues.text: Hey son, hey. Ruiz opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: RUIZ
dialogues.text: Captain.

dialogues.speaker: STEELE
dialogues.text: Lorenzo? How're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: RUIZ
dialogues.text: I went in and out. Medic says I should be okay in a couple of days.

dialogues.speaker: STEELE
dialogues.text: That's great news.

dialogues.speaker: RUIZ
dialogues.text: Are we going after them?

dialogues.speaker: STEELE
dialogues.text: You bet your ass we will. We gotta regroup.

dialogues.speaker: RUIZ
dialogues.text: Don't go out there without me. Don't go back out there without me. I can still do my job. Steele puts his hand on Ruiz' face.

dialogues.speaker: STEELE
dialogues.text: Now you get some rest now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eversmann comes over to Hoot, who is picking through supplies... resupplying himself. Hoot goes about his business... taping grenade pins one after another after another... Calmly, efficiently...

dialogues.speaker: EVERSMANN
dialogues.text: (incredibly) You're going back in? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOOT
dialogues.text: (nods, matter of fact) There's still men out there... God damn! He stops resupplying and picks up a plate and eats.

dialogues.speaker: HOOT
dialogues.text: When I go home... and people ask me, hey Hoot? Why do you do it man? Why? You some kind of war junkie? I won't say a god damned word. Why? Because they won't understand... They won't understand why we do it. They won't understand, it's about the men next to you... and that's it... that's all it is. Eversmann does know... and starts to resupply himself. Ho shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: HOOT
dialogues.text: Hey. Don't even think about it, all right? I'm better on my own. And fully resupplied Hoot simply starts off... Eversmann watches Hoot walk away... And Hoot suddenly slows, realizing... shouting back...

dialogues.speaker: HOOT
dialogues.text: (congratulations) Hey! We started a whole new week... it's Monday. And as he moves off... just another soldier, one of the d of war...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids play on the downed helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: EVERSMANN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was talking to Blackburn the other day, and he asked me, "You know what changed? Why are we going home?" And I said, "Nothing..." But that's not true, you know? I think everything's changed. I know I've changed...  287 127.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fluorescent lights... too bright.. too constant... a cool humming... it kicks off and then on again...and we see EVERSMANN... And he's clean... just some nicks and cuts, band-aid pieces over some small wounds... but there are o wounds, the kind you can't see at first glance...a soldie who's been in combat... a look in a young man's eyes... a look that makes you stop and take a deeper look... into h soul... and that's just what we do... looking at his face into his eyes...into the window of his soul... as he's ta to someone... easy, conversational... nothing out of the ordinary...

dialogues.speaker: EVERSMANN
dialogues.text: You know, a friend of mine asked me before I got here, it was when we were all shipping out. He asked me... "why are you going to fight somebody else's war? What do ya'll think you're heros...?" He laughs at the idea...

dialogues.speaker: EVERSMANN
dialogues.text: I didn't know what to say at the time, but... if he asks me again...I'd say...No. I'd say there's no way in hell...nobody asks to be a hero...it just sometimes turns out that way... And for the first time we see he's been talking to a fami man, lying motionless on a stretcher... And Eversmann, needing to make a final connection touches Smith's chest... a hero's heart... another somebody who d ask to be a hero..

dialogues.speaker: EVERSMANN
dialogues.text: (simply) I'm gonna talk to your ma and pa when I get home, okay? And we see there are other men on stretchers, other young men who left a piece of their hearts behind... And he turns and leaves...the lights forever on...the coo humming... the boys going home men...  288 128.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cargo bay door closes on the empty cargo bay. FADE TO BLACK... LEGEND #1: During the raid over 1000 Somalis died and 19 American soldiers lost their lives. CWO Donovan Briley Staff Sgt. Daniel Busch Spec. James Ca Staff Sgt. William Cleveland Staff Sgt. Thomas Field Sgt. First Class Earl Fillmore CWO Raymond Frank Master Sgt. G Gordon Sgt. Cornell Houston Sgt. Casey Joyce Pfc. Richard Kowalewski Pfc. James Martin Master Sgt. Tim â€œGriz' Marti Sgt. Dominick Pilla Sgt. First Class Matt Rierson Sgt. Lo Ruiz Sgt. First Class Randy Shughart Cpl. Jamie Smith Cwo Cliff â€œElvis' Wolcott

dialogues.speaker: RUIZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: My love, you're strong and you'll do well in life. I love you and my children deeply. Today and tomorrow, with each day, grow and grow. Keep smiling and never give up, even when things get you down. So in closing my love, tonight, tuck my children in bed warmly. Tell them I love them. Then, hug them for me and, give them both a kiss good night for Daddy. Legend #2: Delta Sgts. Gary Gordon and Randy Shughart wer the first soldiers to receive the medal of honor posthumo since the Vietnam War. Michael Durant was released after 11 days of captivity. Two weeks later, President Clinton withdrew Delta Force a The Rangers from Somalia. Legend #3 Major General William F. Garrison accepted full responsibility for the outcome of the raid. On August 2, 1996, Warlord Mohamed Farrah Aidid was kille in Mogadishu. The following day, General Garrison retired
